author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Who Is Yair Lapid, Israel’s Would-Be Prime Minister?
description: Benjamin Netanyahu dismissed the former television host and centrist opposition leader as a lightweight. Now Mr. Lapid has a chance to oust him.
content: JERUSALEM — Yair Lapid, the centrist politician and former media celebrity whose party took second place in Israel’s March election, had pledged to forgo the premiership if that’s what it would take to form a coalition of diverse parties that could oust Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu from power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: U.K. Vote Is Likely to Back Boris Johnson, and Scottish Separatists
description: The prime minister’s Conservative Party stands to gain at the polls on Thursday, despite ethical accusations against him. But growth in support for the Scottish National Party could create turmoil.
content: LONDON — For an ordinary politician, heading into midterm elections on an unsavory plume of scandal over cellphone contacts with billionaires and a suspiciously funded apartment makeover might seem like the recipe for a thumping. But Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain is not an ordinary politician.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Shrinking Society in Japan
description: The persistently low birthrate in the country has caused the population to contract. The U.S. is on a similar path.
content: Japan is the “grayest” nation in the world. Close to 30 percent of the population is over 65, and the population has been shrinking since 2007.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Grading Biden on the F.D.R. Curve
description: Is the Biden honeymoon over? For some, it never started.
content: If you’re fully vaccinated, you might give President Biden an A-plus on his first 100 days. But how’s he doing on everything else?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: With Victory over Astros, the Yankees Have a Winning Record
description: A raucous home crowd helped power an easy win. The Mets, meanwhile, are dealing with an injury to Jacob deGrom.
content: Boos and bad words streamed loudly from the seats in the Houston Astros’ return to Yankee Stadium, and the Yankees got a homer and four hits from Giancarlo Stanton to sate those spiteful fans with a 7-3 victory Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Can the Biden Agenda Fix Middle America’s Deepest Problem?
description: One key economic goal is to create the virtuous cycles of innovation and jobs that already occur in many coastal cities.
content: Last week, the Census Bureau said the last decade’s population growth was the slowest in generations. Also last week, President Biden addressed Congress and laid out a wide-ranging, multi-trillion dollar economic agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jade-Snow Joachim
title: Vaccines, Facebook, Alex Trebek: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: This New Covid Vaccine Could Bring Hope to the Unvaccinated World
description: The German company CureVac hopes its RNA vaccine will rival those made by Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech. It could be ready next month.
content: In early 2020, dozens of scientific teams scrambled to make a vaccine for Covid-19. Some chose tried-and-true techniques, such as making vaccines from killed viruses. But a handful of companies bet on a riskier method, one that had never produced a licensed vaccine: deploying a genetic molecule called RNA.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: A Moderna vaccine booster will be effective against some variants, a trial indicates.
description: A booster, administered six to eight months after the initial vaccination, increased the level of antibodies against variants first identified in South Africa and Brazil.
content: A single dose of the Moderna coronavirus vaccine given as a booster rapidly increased the level of antibodies in people who had already been vaccinated, the company announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elliot Ackerman
title: A ‘Right Stuff’ for Our Moment of Space Travel
description: In “Test Gods,” Nicholas Schmidle tells the story of Virgin Galactic’s space program, with a focus on the astronauts who are charting new frontiers.
content: TEST GODSVirgin Galactic and the Making of a Modern AstronautBy Nicholas Schmidle
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Heller
title: These Four Stage Directors Know Just What Needs to Change
description: The pandemic pause has prompted a prizewinning cohort to ask hard questions about salaries, working in other media and choosing collaboration over “scarcity.”
content: By most measures, they’re doing great. Four prizewinning directors with notable Off Broadway résumés, working with such breakout writers as Aleshea Harris, Will Arbery and Ming Peiffer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor and Amelia Nierenberg
title: What Teen Vaccines Mean for School Reopenings
description: Adolescents could soon be eligible for Covid-19 vaccines, making full, in-person school even more likely.
content: Anyone with a 12-to-15-year-old in their life got encouraging news this week when our colleagues reported that the Food and Drug Administration is set to authorize the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for use in this age group by early next week. On Tuesday, Pfizer said it also expected to apply in September for authorization to administer its Covid-19 vaccine to children ages 2 to 11.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Choral Music
description: Listen to the gorgeous sound of a mass of voices: ancient, contemporary, gospel, opera, sacred, romantic.
content: In the past, we’ve chosen the five minutes or so we would play to make our friends fall in love with classical music, the piano, opera, the cello, Mozart, 21st-century composers, the violin, Baroque music, sopranos, Beethoven, the flute, string quartets, tenors and Brahms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mahua Moitra
title: I Know What It Takes to Defeat Narendra Modi
description: West Bengal’s voters showed they won’t put up with his misogyny and divisive politics.
content: KOLKATA, India — I am a member of the Indian Parliament, and on Sunday, the political party I belong to, the All India Trinamool Congress, defeated the party of Prime Minister Narendra Modi in elections for the West Bengal State legislature. Our party and my leader, Mamata Banerjee, the only female chief minister of a state in India today, showed what it takes to defeat Mr. Modi’s divisive, misogynist politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Atlanta Officer Who Fatally Shot Rayshard Brooks Is Reinstated
description: The officer, Garrett Rolfe, faces murder and aggravated assault charges, but officials determined that his firing violated his due process rights.
content: ATLANTA — Garrett Rolfe, the Atlanta police officer who was fired from his job after fatally shooting a Black man, Rayshard Brooks, in a fast-food parking lot, was reinstated on Wednesday by the city’s Civil Service Board, which found that Officer Rolfe’s firing violated his due process rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Pawel
title: How Nervous Should Gavin Newsom Be?
description: All signs suggest the governor should prevail. But Democrats need to weigh what is best for the state against what is best for the party.
content: LOS ANGELES — Two events that attracted scant notice on Nov. 6, 2020, speak to how quickly political fortunes can change in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Pfizer-BioNTech Vaccine is Highly Effective Against Variants, Studies Find
description: Two studies showed the vaccine to be more than 95 percent effective at protecting against severe disease or death from the variants first identified in South Africa and the U.K.
content: The Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine is extraordinarily effective at protecting against severe disease caused by two dangerous variants, according to two studies published Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Catie Edmondson
title: House Republicans Have Had Enough of Liz Cheney’s Truth-Telling
description: G.O.P. House members are plotting a fresh bid to dethrone Ms. Cheney from her leadership post. Her transgression: continued repudiation of Donald J. Trump and his false election claims.
content: WASHINGTON — The first time defenders of Donald J. Trump came for Representative Liz Cheney, for the offense of having voted to impeach him, fellow Republicans closed ranks to save her leadership post, with Representative Kevin McCarthy boasting that their “big tent” party had enough room for both the former president and a stalwart critic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Wortham
title: The Artist Upending Photography’s Brutal Racial Legacy
description: Deana Lawson’s regal, loving, unburdened photographs imagine a world in which Black people are free from the distortions of history.
content: A few months ago, the photographer Deana Lawson and her family were driving to an art opening in the Inglewood neighborhood of Los Angeles when Lawson spotted a garage sale out of the corner of her eye. She wanted to pull over, but her 19-year-old son was tired, and he balked. The family passed the sale again on their way back home, and this time, Lawson insisted. When she met an elderly woman tending to the sale, she knew immediately that she wanted to photograph her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Cecilia Kang
title: British Political Veteran Steers Facebook’s Trump Decision
description: Nick Clegg, a former deputy prime minister, has shaped the company’s handling of Donald Trump at every turn.
content: When Facebook barred President Donald J. Trump from its service in January, Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive, defended the decision in a Facebook post the morning after the siege of the Capitol. But the first draft was written the night before by Nick Clegg, a former British deputy prime minister who leads the company’s public affairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elliot Ackerman
title: The Afghanistan War Will End as It Began: In Blood
description: "America might be done with Afghanistan, but Afghanistan isn’t done with America."
content: This past week saw a spate of violence as the Biden administration began its withdrawal from Afghanistan. On Friday, a truck laden with explosives detonated south of Kabul, killing 27. On Saturday, a professor at Kabul University was fatally shot, and that same day Kandahar airfield came under rocket attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Facebook Oversight Board Upholds Social Network’s Ban of Trump
description: A company-appointed panel ruled that the ban was justified at the time but added that the company should reassess its action and make a final decision in six months.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — A Facebook-appointed panel of journalists, activists and lawyers on Wednesday upheld the social network’s ban of former President Donald J. Trump, ending any immediate return by Mr. Trump to mainstream social media and renewing a debate about tech power over online speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: ‘History Is Watching.’ Here are 5 key arguments from Liz Cheney’s opinion essay.
description: Representative Liz Cheney, Republican of Wyoming, defended her views on her party’s behavior and Donald J. Trump in an essay published in The Washington Post.
content: Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming, who has been one of the most outspoken Republican critics of the party’s conduct surrounding President Biden’s victory and the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol, defended her views in a pointed opinion essay published by The Washington Post on Wednesday as she faced an increasing likelihood of being ousted from House leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California Reaches More Reopening Milestones
description: Wednesday: The state is reopening, but some regions aren’t moving as quickly as others. Also: A bear hits the recall campaign trail.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

description: When Bill and Melinda Gates announced filed for divorce in Washington State on Monday, grant recipients and staff members alike wondered what would happen to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

author: By Edmund Lee
title: Fox News keeps profits flowing at Murdoch’s Fox Corporation.
description: Revenue at Fox Corporation dropped as fewer viewers tuned into the company’s cable channels and the Fox broadcast network. The company also announced the acquisition of OutKick Media.
content: Fox News, the cable news giant controlled by Rupert Murdoch, kept its parent company flush in the first three months of the year, notching a slight gain in profit and sales despite a drop in viewers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Wide-Angle Oddity: Giant Bidens Meet Tiny Carters
description: A picture of two presidents and first ladies led to many Hobbit jokes online. We explain what happened.
content: It was a pleasant 86 or so degrees in Plains, Ga., when President Biden and Jill Biden visited former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn Carter, at their home on April 29.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israeli President Taps the Opposition Leader Lapid to Form Government
description: Yair Lapid has four weeks to cobble together a coalition, after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu failed in his attempt. But the process could end in another election.
content: JERUSALEM — Yair Lapid, the centrist leader of the Israeli opposition, was asked Wednesday to try to form a coalition government after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu failed to do so by a Tuesday deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kreda
title: Rangers in Turmoil: Brawls on the Ice Follow Front Office Firings
description: President John Davidson and General Manager Jeff Gorton lost their jobs, and then the team started settling scores with the Washington Capitals two days after Tom Wilson attacked two Rangers.
content: A day of upheaval for the Rangers started with the ouster of two top executives and ended with a game between two teams that had a score to settle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Hiltner
title: The Dream: International Travel. The Reality: Chaos and Confusion.
description: The world beckons, especially for those who have been vaccinated, but would-be travelers face a difficult moment when travel possibilities are at odds with the facts of a still reeling world.
content: In recent days, a steady stream of promising news has painted a rosy picture of the return of international leisure travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Rebecca Robbins
title: Taking ‘Extraordinary Measures,’ Biden Backs Suspending Patents on Vaccines
description: The Biden administration, siding with some world leaders over the U.S. pharmaceutical industry, came out in favor of waiving intellectual property protections for coronavirus vaccines.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration came out on Wednesday in support of waiving intellectual property protections for coronavirus vaccines, siding with international efforts to bolster production amid concerns about vaccine access in developing nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Blinken, on Ukraine Trip, Will Offer Support on Russia but Also Pressure on Corruption
description: The secretary of state will reassure Kyiv of backing against Russian hostilities, but call for more determined efforts to clean up the political system.
content: LONDON — As Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken arrived in Ukraine early Thursday, he encountered an all too familiar scene: a country struggling to defend itself from without and reconstruct itself from within.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: When Loyalty Is Overrated
description: Sometimes what we are most devoted to are our biggest mistakes.
content: My wife hates my car, a Jeep Wrangler Rubicon. She hates the way it handles, and the noise it makes and how big the tires are. Once, she suggested that she’d be more comfortable if I took her riding in a high-speed steam shovel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: In Video, French Reporter Who Vanished in Mali Says He Was Kidnapped
description: In a short clip that circulated online, the journalist, Olivier Dubois, said he had been seized by a jihadist group linked to Al Qaeda and urged the French government to secure his release.
content: PARIS — A French journalist who went missing in Mali last month said in a video that circulated Wednesday on social media, but that could not be independently verified, that he had been kidnapped by a jihadist group operating in the region as he appealed for help from the authorities in France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: How Have You Commemorated Milestones During the Pandemic?
description: What coming-of-age traditions have you had to cancel or change over the past year? What new rituals have you created to celebrate your teenage years?
content: What teenage milestones have you always looked forward to? Getting your driver’s license? Going to the prom? Graduating from high school? Celebrating your quinceañera, bar or bat mitzvah, or Sweet Sixteen?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Are You Flourishing?
description: Asking the question is a start.
content: Welcome. What would it take for you to flourish? To wake up eager to begin the day rather than burrow back into the covers? Flourishing — a combination of physical, emotional and mental well-being — is the opposite of languishing, that joyless blah feeling that’s been a feature of recent months for so many of us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: ‘There Was a Big Battle in Here’: Lawyers Tour Capitol as a Crime Scene
description: Defense lawyers representing suspects in the riot are being given tours of the Capitol to help them visualize what took place on Jan. 6.
content: WASHINGTON — “This is the speaker’s lobby,” said Thomas Loyd, the Capitol Police inspector, his voice rising so those in the back could hear. “This is where the shooting took place.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Patricia Mazzei
title: Why Democratic Departures From the House Have Republicans Salivating
description: A growing number of Democrats in battleground districts are either retiring or leaving to seek higher office, imperiling the party’s control of the House and President Biden’s expansive agenda.
content: WASHINGTON — With 18 months left before the midterms, a spate of Democratic departures from the House is threatening to erode the party’s slim majority in the House and imperil President Biden’s far-reaching policy agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Annie Karni
title: Biden Leans Into Plans to Tax the Rich
description: “We’re not going to deprive any of these executives of their second or third home, travel privately by jet,” the president said at the White House.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden delivered a clear and punchy message to America’s highest earners on Wednesday: I’m going to raise your taxes, but your vacation homes are safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: James Brandon Lewis, a Saxophonist Who Embodies and Transcends Tradition
description: His new album, “Jesup Wagon,” is a tribute to another polymathic figure who insisted on cutting his own path: George Washington Carver.
content: When James Brandon Lewis plays the saxophone, he usually plants his feet shoulder width apart and bends a bit at the knee, swaying and tunneling into a rhythmic flow. As a bandleader, he almost exclusively performs his own compositions, which have melodies that roam, dart and soar but often stay grounded in a pulse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Bankers, Please Return to Your Desks
description: Goldman Sachs is the latest to call an end to remote work.
content: Goldman Sachs has joined JPMorgan Chase in telling its bankers that it’s almost time to come back to the office. David Solomon, Goldman’s C.E.O., sent a memo to employees advising them to “make plans to be in a position to return to the office” by June 14 in the U.S. and June 21 in Britain. JPMorgan plans to open its offices on May 17 on a voluntary basis and require that workers return to their desks in rotations starting in July.
source.name: The New York Times

description: This word has appeared in 59 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

author: By Russell Janzen
title: Only Connect: Yearning for the Intimacy of a Danced, Onstage World
description: Russell Janzen of City Ballet misses the physical and emotional closeness forged onstage, which are lost on Zoom and in socially distanced dancing.
content: When the music begins, we start to dance. It’s early April, and for the first time in 13 months I’m rehearsing with a partner in the New York City Ballet studios. Ashley Bouder and I bump into each other as we dance side by side. After more than a year of dancing on our own we’re not used to this sort of closeness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Coming Soon to a Hallowed Hall of Spaceflight: An X-Wing Fighter
description: Starting late next year, an X-wing from “Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker” will go on display at the National Air and Space Museum in Washington.
content: The National Air and Space Museum holds some of the most hallowed objects of the aerial age.

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Global hunger, maternal deaths and stillbirths have soared during the pandemic.
description: The number of people requiring emergency food aid hit a five-year high in 2020 — at least 155 million — while the risk of maternal and newborn deaths surged.
content: The pandemic has contributed to soaring hunger and acute declines in maternal health care that threaten tens of millions of people, the United Nations said Wednesday, underscoring the disproportionate spillover effects on the world’s poor.

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Has a New Contender for Weirdest Presidential Photo Ever
description: The Bidens visited the Carters the other day, and Jimmy Fallon, Seth Meyers and Trevor Noah are still trying to get their minds around the result.

title: Emissions Cuts Could Drop the Impact of Melting Ice on Oceans by Half
description: A new study said that limiting warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius could reduce sea level rise from melting ice sheets from about 10 inches to about five by 2100.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Schwendener
title: Can’t Find a Ticket to Frieze? Try a Satellite Fair
description: Zürcher Gallery on Bleecker Street shows what fairs are good at: bringing new artists to your attention.
content: If you can’t buy tickets for Frieze at the Shed, you can still attend a satellite fair like “The 11 Women of Spirit” at Zürcher Gallery, which is essentially a group show of female artists, now in its third iteration. description: The No. 3 Republican in the House faces a party uprising over her acknowledgment of reality.

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Rozette Rago
title: Repairing Generations of Trauma, One Lotus Flower at a Time
description: Buddhists from many cultures and communities gathered to repair the nation’s racial karma. The ceremony was held at a Los Angeles temple that had recently been vandalized in an arson attack.

source.name: The New York Times

title: David Oyelowo Fights for Representation in Family Films
description: The actor turned to directing after an eye-opening discussion with his son. He realized he couldn’t rely on Hollywood to find stories he wanted to tell.

description: Markets gyrated this week on concern that the Federal Reserve may lift rates earlier. But its policymakers stuck with their patient script on Wednesday.
content: Inflation jitters are popping up in earnings call chatter, spooking investors and dominating business television talk shows. One place they aren’t taking over, it appears, is the Federal Reserve.

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Constitutional Challenges Loom Over Proposed Voting Bill
description: The sprawling legislation, known as H.R. 1, could result in lawsuits leading to a dozen Supreme Court cases, legal experts said.
content: WASHINGTON — If the sweeping voting rights bill that the House passed in March overcomes substantial hurdles in the Senate to become law, it would reshape American elections and represent a triumph for Democrats eager to combat the wave of election restrictions moving through Republican-controlled state legislatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $750,000 Homes in Pennsylvania, New York and Georgia
description: A circa-1900 brick house in Lancaster, a one-bedroom condo in New York City and a two-bedroom condo overlooking Troup Square in Savannah.
content: This property is in School Lane Hills, a neighborhood about a mile west of the city of Lancaster, so it is within walking distance of Lancaster Central Market, the Fulton Theatre and numerous shops and restaurants. It is a few blocks south of Buchanan Park and the campus of Franklin & Marshall College. Wheatland, the Federal-style house to which President James Buchanan retired after failing to prevent the United States from descending into civil war, is a mile down the road (you can visit the house virtually during the pandemic).

author: By Ellen Rosen
title: Operating Rooms Go Under the Knife
description: Hospitals are bringing together surgeons, anesthesiologists and nurses with architects, engineers and administrative staff to rethink the modern operating room.

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Federal Judge Strikes Down Moratorium on Evicting Renters
description: The Biden administration will appeal the ruling against the policy, which has been the subject of legal challenges by landlords.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Wednesday struck down the nationwide moratorium on evictions imposed by the Trump administration last year and extended by President Biden until June 30, a ruling that could affect tenants struggling to pay rent during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: The N.B.A.’s Play-In Tournament Isn’t the Problem
description: Though stars like LeBron James and Luka Doncic have complained about the pre-playoff hurdle, the stress of the play-in matters less than injuries and the compressed season.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: 2 Americans Sentenced to Life in Prison for Murder of Italian Police Officer
description: The two American men were teenagers in July 2019 when an early-morning scuffle with two plainclothes police officers in Rome turned deadly.
content: ROME — Two American men were found guilty of murder on Wednesday and sentenced to life in prison for the street-corner killing of an Italian military police officer on an early summer morning, when the two young San Francisco natives were vacationing in Rome.

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: What Is the Facebook Oversight Board?
description: The panel of about 20 people, including academics and political leaders, upheld the company’s ban of former President Donald J. Trump.

author: By Dorie Greenspan
title: The Jam-Filled Pastry of My Dreams
description: A serendipitous trip in the Basque Country led Dorie Greenspan to this irresistible dessert.
content: Fourteen or so months into Covid-times and more than 450 days since we left our home in Paris thinking we’d be back in a few weeks, I keep dreaming of travel. One morning, I woke up thinking I was on a beach, not my usual dreamscape, but nice. Once, I dreamed I’d bought so many lilies of the valley on May Day that I couldn’t carry them home. And recently, I dreamed that the first batch of strawberries had hit the Paris markets — they looked beautiful next to the early asparagus. When my dreams took me to Basque Country, I woke up my husband so that we could talk about the real trip we took there more than a decade before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: How One Graphic Novel Looks at Anti-Asian Hate
description: In “Cyclopedia Exotica,” the artist and writer Aminder Dhaliwal created a fictitious community facing xenophobia, fetishization and media misrepresentation. It’s resonating with her thousands of Instagram followers.

title: A Religious Community and the Weed Farm in the Middle of It
description: The Arizona town of Snowflake has two great institutions.
content: SNOWFLAKE, Ariz. — The Latter-day Saints temple looms over the landscape, its smooth granite exterior bright in the high desert sun. At the top, a golden angel glimmers in the light.

author: By Victor Mather
title: Athletes Stranded After Suspension of the Indian Premier League
description: The massive cricket competition, being played in a bubble despite India’s outbreak, was half over when positive tests shut it down.
content: The Indian Premier League provides international cricket stars with their most lucrative paydays of the year. The annual event in cricket-mad India draws television viewers from around the world and pays top players as much as $2 million for two months’ work.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Used to Like School’: An 11-Year-Old’s Struggle With Pandemic Learning
description: Without home internet, Jordyn Coleman has had trouble staying connected to remote classes during the coronavirus pandemic.
content: CLARKSDALE, Miss. — By the time Precious Coleman returned home from her overnight shift at a casino, it was past 9 in the morning. It had been another night of dealing with belligerent patrons who refused to wear their face masks and drunks who needed to be escorted to the curb. Her eyes stung.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Some hospitals don’t have enough oxygen to keep patients alive. Here’s why.
description: The pandemic’s latest horror is that people around the world are dying for lack of access to medical oxygen, especially in India. Each day, tens of thousands of people are admitted to hospitals with Covid-19, driving the demand for the oxygen far beyond the supply.
content: The pandemic’s latest horror is that people around the world are dying for lack of access to medical oxygen, especially in India. Each day, tens of thousands of people are admitted to hospitals with Covid-19, driving the demand for the oxygen far beyond the supply.

title: Two Important Moves on Emissions
description: Congress and the Biden administration are taking action aimed at sharply restricting a pair of potent greenhouse gases.
content: Over the past week, Congress and the Biden administration took their first concrete steps to reduce emissions of two dangerous greenhouse gases: Methane, which is emitted during  natural gas extraction and by leaks from oil and gas wells, and hydrofluorocarbons, which are used in refrigeration and air-conditioning systems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A new RNA vaccine could announce results from its late-stage trial as early as next week.
content: As terrifying outbreaks erupt around the world, governments are scrambling to tap into the global supply of vaccines. But with so few doses to go around, many countries, particularly those in the developing world, are looking toward an upcoming “second wave” of vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: The vaccine divide.
content: The Biden administration on Wednesday came out in support of waiving intellectual property protections for Covid-19 vaccines, a breakthrough for international efforts to increase vaccine access.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ioan Grillo and Adriana Zehbrauskas
title: Will Nayib Bukele Be Latin America’s Next Strongman?
description: The president of El Salvador is a stress test for his country's democracy.
content: EL MOZOTE, El Salvador — The village of El Mozote sits in the department of Morazán in the northeastern highlands of El Salvador near the border with Honduras, a huddle of concrete block homesteads, many of loggers and farmers, nestled between fertile peaks rich with pineapple, coffee and sugar cane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marion Renault
title: Flat Pasta That Turns Into 3-D Shapes — Just Add Boiling Water
description: The engineers are in the kitchen, again.
content: Don’t be fooled. This pasta may look like your average fettuccine. But cook it for seven minutes in boiling water and it will transform, coiling into a neat spiral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: The variant found in N.Y.C. doesn’t seem to lead to more severe infections, a preliminary study finds.
description: The findings, published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, are the latest sign that the city may have dodged a worst-case scenario with the variant, B.1.526, even as risks remain.
content: The coronavirus variant first discovered in New York City does not appear to be leading to more severe infections, or causing re-infections at a significantly higher rate than older forms of the virus, according to a new, preliminary analysis by city health officials that was published by the Centers for Disease and Control and Prevention on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Texas Lawyer Gets 15 Years for Scheme to Defraud Cocaine Traffickers
description: A lawyer known as the D.W.I. Dude pocketed money that he told drug dealers would be used to bribe officials, prosecutors said.
content: A Texas lawyer known as the D.W.I. Dude for specializing in defending clients charged with driving while intoxicated and drug possession was sentenced this week to more than 15 years in prison for a scheme to pocket money that Colombian cocaine traffickers had been told would go to bribe officials, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: The U.S. Birthrate Has Dropped Again. The Pandemic May Be Accelerating the Decline.
description: Over all, the birthrate declined by 4 percent in 2020. Births were down most sharply in December, when babies conceived at the start of the health crisis would have been born.
content: The birthrate declined for the sixth straight year in 2020, the federal government reported on Wednesday, early evidence that the coronavirus pandemic accelerated a trend among American women of delaying pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: An unequal global recovery.
content: In much of the developed world, vaccine orders are soaring and economies are poised to roar back to life. But in poorer nations, the virus rages on. In India, people are gasping for oxygen; thousands are dying daily in Brazil, and vaccination progress in countries as varied as Ghana and Bangladesh has faltered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Lounging Around
description: What story does this image inspire for you?
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Walking in Light on the High Line
description: Okwui Okpokwasili’s processional is a homage and farewell to Simone Leigh’s giant bronze bust, “Brick House.”
content: First we saw them, bright loops of light, walking. Then as they approached, we heard: vocal harmonies holding, shifting, droning, keening; a shared sound of moving parts, in search of something but in no hurry to find it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Child’s Grave Is Earliest Known Burial Site in Africa
description: A child laid to rest in 78,000 years ago, yields clues to early human burials in East Africa.
content: Researchers have identified the earliest known human burial in Africa at Panga ya Saidi, a cave near the Kenyan coast. A child, probably a boy of about 2-1/2 to 3 years old, was placed in a pit about 78,000 years ago, laid carefully on his side, curled up, likely with some kind of pillow under his head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: As Covid Ravages Poorer Countries, Rich Nations Spring Back to Life
description: Despite early vows, the developed world has done little to promote global vaccination, in what analysts call both a moral and epidemiological failure.
content: The contrast could hardly be sharper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The Blue Jays Will Fly North, but Not All the Way to Canada
description: The team still cannot return to Toronto, but on June 1 its home games will shift from Florida to a Class AAA park in Buffalo.
content: The Toronto Blue Jays will finally end their extended stay in Florida, returning to a familiar place up north this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What the Extended Eviction Moratorium Means for New York
description: Hundreds of thousands of tenants are still struggling to pay rent.

title: His Ship Vanished in the Arctic 176 Years Ago. DNA Has Offered a Clue.
description: For the first time, researchers have identified the remains of a sailor from the doomed 1845 Franklin expedition of the fabled Northwest Passage.
content: On July 9, 1845, two months after departing from Greenhithe, England, Warrant Officer John Gregory wrote a letter to his wife from Greenland in which he described seeing whales and icebergs for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Indian Official Self-Isolates at G7 Talks After Possible Covid Exposure
description: Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, India’s foreign minister, is in London for meetings before a June summit of leaders from the world’s top industrial powers.
content: LONDON — India’s foreign minister, visiting London for a gathering of ministers from the world’s top industrial powers, said on Wednesday that he was self-isolating after coming into contact with people who tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A Rare Peek Inside a Semi-Secret ‘Secret Garden’
description: The 2018 workshop for a possible revival of the lush musical was never meant to be seen by the public, but will now stream as a benefit this weekend.
content: When Marsha Norman suggested to the producer Jerry Goehring the idea of streaming the 2018 workshop of a stalled Broadway revival of “The Secret Garden” as a benefit, he thought it was a great idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Weiner
title: The Weight-Loss Industry Is Coming for Our Post-Lockdown Bodies
description: Don't worry about the "quarantine 15" or pay for expensive diet products. Take small steps and make healthier choices instead.
content: Perhaps you’ve heard someone bemoan the “quarantine 15” that they’ve gained during lockdown, or their struggles to “flatten the curve” of a body that looks different after a year inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: The world’s vaccine crisis is an ominous sign for the fight against climate change.
description: The stark gap in vaccination rates between the world’s rich and poor countries is emerging as a test for how the world responds to another global challenge: Averting the worst effects of climate change.
content: The stark gap in vaccination rates between the world’s rich and poor countries is emerging as a test for how the world responds to another global challenge: Averting the worst effects of climate change.

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Shane Goldmacher
title: Facebook Ban Hits Trump Where It Hurts: Messaging and Money
description: Facebook has increasingly become one of the most vital weapons in a political campaign’s arsenal, and few had tapped into its potential for advertising and fund-raising as aggressively as Mr. Trump’s.
content: The decision by Facebook on Wednesday to keep former President Donald J. Trump off its platform could have significant consequences for his political operation as he tries to remain the leader of the Republican Party, thwarting his ability to amplify his message to tens of millions of followers and hampering his fund-raising ability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: To Save Penn Station, New York Wants to Build 10 Skyscrapers
description: The state says revenue from the new towers can finance the rebuilding of the rail terminal. But the pandemic has upended the need for office space.
content: For years, one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s top priorities has been an enormous development in the heart of Manhattan that would be among the largest real estate projects ever built in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: A Farmer Moved a 200-Year-Old Stone, and the French-Belgian Border
description: A marker that was moved seven feet into French territory by a farmer in Belgium might have changed the countries’ border forever if not for a sharp-eyed group of friends.
content: When it comes to redrawing nations’ borders, scores of diplomats can spend years painstakingly hashing out every inch of the dividing line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: She Kept Madrid Open in the Pandemic. Voters Rewarded Her.
description: Isabel Díaz Ayuso, a conservative politician dubbed a “Trumpista” by her opponents, won the Madrid regional election by a landslide after she refused to shut down the capital’s bars and shops.
content: MADRID — She is a conservative who campaigned on a slogan that came down to one word: Freedom. She offered herself as a champion of small business and scoffed at national coronavirus restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Johnny Crawford, a Western Hero’s Son on ‘The Rifleman,’ Dies at 75
description: For five TV seasons he was at the side of Chuck Connors’s widowed sharpshooter. He also had some success as a pop singer, film actor and bandleader.
content: Johnny Crawford, the soulful young actor who became a child star on the western “The Rifleman” in the late 1950s and had some success as a pop singer, died on April 29 in Los Angeles. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James S. Hirsch
title: Willie Mays Carries the Torch for His Generation
description: On the occasion of baseball’s oldest living Hall of Famer turning 90, a reflection on the conditioning that powered his greatness.
content: I once asked Willie Mays what his proudest achievement was in baseball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Good Riddance, Donald Trump?
description: A Facebook-appointed panel avoided a clear decision about Trump’s heinous online behavior. It’s kind of perfect, actually.
content: It never occurred to me that a Facebook-appointed panel could avoid a clear decision about Donald Trump’s heinous online behavior. But that is what it’s done.

author: By The Learning Network
title: Annotated by the Author: Writing Reader Responses
description: Judy Wang and Nina Nzekwe, winners of our 2020 Summer Reading Contest, show us how to respond to texts both personally and critically.
content: In our “Annotated by the Author” series, we invite New York Times journalists and winners of our student contests to comment on their work to help demystify the writing and research process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Guerrero
title: Broaden the Audience for Puzzles? She’s Game.
description: Everdeen Mason, The Times’s first editorial director of Games, wants to keep challenging current players while reaching new ones. “We have to get people out of their comfort zones a little bit.”
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Fry in a Shallow Pan
description: A trio of debut constructors dazzle.

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: Vira Sathidar, Cultural Figure Who Fought India’s Caste System, Dies at 62
description: After a career of activism on behalf of the lower castes, Mr. Sathidar was cast in a movie that reflected his life. He died of complications of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas St. Fleur
title: Watch the Eta Aquariids Meteor Shower Peak in Night Skies
description: Meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.
content: All year long as Earth revolves around the sun, it passes through streams of cosmic debris. The resulting meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘Girls5Eva,’ ‘Rutherford Falls’ and the Nostalgia Trap
description: Peacock, the streaming platform, relies on must-see reminiscing in two shows that are also warnings about living in the past.
content: The best throwaway joke in “30 Rock” — a category in which there is a thousand-way tie for first — comes in a 2011 episode, where we see NBC’s comeback plan in pie-chart form. A yellow wedge reads, “Make it 1997 again through science or magic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: The 17 Best Recipes Our Food Staff Cooked Last Month
description: In April, we felt inspired to try new recipes and to safely gather with family and friends over good food.
content: Perhaps the biggest surprise for many of us this April was the slow return to gathering, made possible by the proliferation of coronavirus vaccines. It felt like being, say, a daffodil. One by one, we poked our heads out from beneath the cold, hard ground of winter and worry, happy to face the sun and one another. The New York Times Food and Cooking team was no exception. After fighting through the cooking fatigue of late winter, we got excited by the arrival of new produce and began safely inviting those we hold dear into our homes and backyards to enjoy the bounty. Here’s what we cooked for ourselves (and others) in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: A Verdict in Facebook’s Show Trial
description: An oversight board essentially kicks the decision over Donald Trump’s status back to the social media site.
content: In the end, they passed the buck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Oremus
title: Trump Is Mark Zuckerberg’s Problem. Again.
description: The former president’s suspension from Facebook continues — for now.
content: Facebook’s Oversight Board on Wednesday upheld the social network’s temporary suspension of Donald Trump but declined to decide when, or whether, that ban should be lifted. The decision dashed the former president’s hopes for a swift reinstatement by a body charged with reviewing the platform’s content moderation practices. But it also sent a message that the scope of the board’s power is limited and that the ultimate responsibility for these questions still lies with Mark Zuckerberg and company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Benjamin Weiser
title: Sheldon Silver, Disgraced Assembly Speaker, Is Furloughed From Prison
description: The longtime Democratic leader was released to home confinement after less than a year of a six-and-a-half year sentence on corruption charges.
content: Sheldon Silver, the former Assembly Democratic speaker who once dominated New York State politics only to have his career end in a conviction on federal corruption charges, was released from prison on Tuesday as he awaits a decision on whether he can complete his sentence at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dashiell Young-Saver
title: Examining the Math and Ethics of Covid-19 in Prisons
description: In this lesson students will analyze graphs, maps and data to better understand the toll of the pandemic on incarcerated populations.
content: Note to Teachers: We have a related “What’s Going On in This Graph?” activity about Covid-19 in prisons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: Biden’s Taiwan Policy Is Truly, Deeply Reckless
description: If the administration continues on this path, it will increase the odds of a catastrophic war.
content: Media coverage of President Biden’s foreign policy tends to focus on his efforts to withdraw from Afghanistan, get tough on Russia and negotiate with Iran. But none of those may prove as consequential as Mr. Biden’s quiet, incremental moves to establish official relations with Taiwan. Because only his policy toward Taiwan is meaningfully increasing the risk of world war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: How Asians Became the Most Vaccinated Group in New York City
description: Sixty-eight percent of the city’s adult Asian population has received at least one dose, despite many New Yorkers of Asian descent facing language barriers and a fear of violence.
content: Since last year, Phung Nguyen, 77, feared the worst would happen if she fell ill with Covid-19. She lives alone in the Bronx, lost contact with her daughter years ago and only speaks Vietnamese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Stacey Abrams Contains Multitudes
description: Her obsessions with public policy and pop culture came together in the new Supreme Court thriller “While Justice Sleeps,” the first time she has used her own name on one of her novels.
content: Stacey Abrams published her first book — “Rules of Engagement,” a romance novel about a brilliant undercover agent and her smoking-hot colleague — while a student at Yale Law School. Eager to keep her worlds separate, she used the nom de plume Selena Montgomery, a homage to the “Bewitched” actress Elizabeth Montgomery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Why Trump Still Has Millions of Americans in His Grip
description: Many of the forces that helped bring him to power have only intensified.
content: Beginning in the mid-1960s, the priorities of the Democratic Party began to shift away from white working- and middle-class voters — many of them socially conservative, Christian and religiously observant — to a set of emerging constituencies seeking rights and privileges previously reserved for white men: African-Americans; women’s rights activists; proponents of ethnic diversity, sexual freedom and self-expressive individualism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: While rich countries come back to life, the virus is ravaging poorer nations.
description: In much of the developed world, vaccine orders are soaring into the billions of doses, coronavirus cases are easing and economies are poised to roar back to life. In many less developed nations, though, the virus is raging on, while vaccinations are far too slow to protect even the most vulnerable.
content: In much of the developed world, vaccine orders are soaring into the billions of doses, coronavirus cases are easing and economies are poised to roar back to life. In many less developed nations, though, the virus is raging on, while vaccinations are far too slow to protect even the most vulnerable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Power Up Your To-Do List
description: The free task-reminder app on your phone can keep you and your projects on track.
content: Getting organized is serious business, judging by the number of checklist and chore-tracker programs available. If you’re new to mobile task-manager software, Apple and Google have their own free apps that combine the convenience of a notes app with the ability to set notification alerts to make sure things get done on time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: France Battles Over Whether to Cancel or Celebrate Napoleon
description: President Emmanuel Macron laid a wreath at the emperor’s tomb on the 200th anniversary of his death, stepping into a national debate over the legacy of Napoleon.
content: PARIS — Jacques Chirac couldn’t stand him. Nicolas Sarkozy kept his distance. François Hollande shunned him. But on the 200th anniversary this week of Napoleon Bonaparte’s death, Emmanuel Macron has chosen to do what most recent presidents of France have avoided: honor the man who in 1799 destroyed the nascent French Republic in a putsch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Daylight Attack on 2 Asian Women in San Francisco Increases Fears
description: The stabbing on Market Street this week and other attacks have caused some older Asian-American residents in the Bay Area to fear going outdoors, community leaders said.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — From her flower stand on Market Street, Patricia Lee saw the glint of a large blade and then feathers from a winter jacket fly through the air. An older woman buckled to her knees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: For Mother’s Day, Movies All About ‘Mother’
description: Mom’s the word — the only word — in the titles of these films to stream that celebrate the darker side of motherhood.
content: Sunday is Mother’s Day, but before you stream a movie with the title “Mother’s Day,” watch out. The one that’s a feel-good comedy just might make mom’s day. The grindhouse exploitation film could ruin her weekend. (Props to the moms whose taste is the reverse.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: Rangers Call N.H.L. Safety Chief ‘Unfit’ After Decision on Tom Wilson
description: The Capitals forward was fined $5,000 a day after he punched the Rangers’ Pavel Buchnevich in the head and tossed a helmetless Artemi Panarin to the ice.
content: A melee on the ice Monday led to more upheaval off it Tuesday as the Rangers called for the dismissal of the N.H.L.’s director of player safety in a scathing statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Limits of Facebook’s ‘Supreme Court’

author: By Edmund Lee
title: The New York Times Tops 7.8 Million Subscribers as Growth Slows
description: The publisher added 301,000 digital subscribers for the first quarter, the slowest gain in over a year. Profits jumped, beating Wall Street expectations.
content: No doubt, President Biden has lowered the temperature of the nation after four years under Donald J. Trump, a tumultuous period capped by the worst pandemic in a century. He may have also lowered interest in the news. For the first quarter, The New York Times Company recorded its smallest gain in new subscribers in a year and a half.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Restaurants and Bars Rush to Apply for New Federal Aid Program
description: The industry’s return will serve as a major test of President Biden’s goal of bringing the country back to some version of normal by this summer.
content: WASHINGTON — A total of 186,200 restaurants, bars and other eligible businesses applied for help from a new $28.6 billion federal aid program in the first two days it was accepting applications, President Biden said on Wednesday, indicating huge demand from a struggling industry for a limited pot of relief funds.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Climate Change Is Not a Subjective Thing.’ How Does the U.S. Approach to the Environment Look From Abroad?
description: From recycling to carbon emissions, we asked 10 people from around the world what they thought of America’s approach to the environment. It didn’t go well.
content: The United States has a schizophrenic relationship with the environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang and Michael Roston
title: SpaceX Successfully Lands Prototype of Mars and Moon Rocket After Test Flight
description: After a series of high-altitude test flights that ended in explosions, the new vehicle set down in one piece on a Texas launchpad.
content: A prototype of a spacecraft that SpaceX hopes one day to send to the moon and Mars touched down in one piece on a landing pad in South Texas on Wednesday. It was the fifth high-altitude flight test of Starship, a vehicle that in several earlier test flights exploded either during or after landing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Nicholas Fandos
title: Cheney hit back at G.O.P. leaders amid mounting efforts to oust her.
description: Representative Liz Cheney offered a pointed response to those vying to remove her from her position as the No. 3 House Republican.
content: Representative Liz Cheney, Republican of Wyoming, hit back at leaders of her own party on Wednesday, warning her colleagues that “history is watching” as they consider expelling her from their leadership ranks for continuing to reject Donald J. Trump’s election lies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Vaccinated 12- to 15-year-olds at U.S. camps will be able to remove masks outdoors, the C.D.C. director says.
description: The agency was criticized over its guidance that campers should wear masks except when eating, drinking, swimming or napping.
content: As federal regulators prepare to authorize use of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine in adolescents aged 12 to 15, a top health official said Wednesday that vaccinated individuals in that age group will be able to remove their masks outdoors at camps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Oscar Robertson Wants Westbrook to Break His Triple-Doubles Record
description: “There’s no doubt about it,” Robertson said. “I hope he gets it.” And he hopes people will stop criticizing Russell Westbrook, the Wizards guard, for not yet winning a championship.
content: In his first N.B.A. game, in October 1960, Oscar Robertson registered 21 points, 12 rebounds and 10 assists for the Cincinnati Royals against the Los Angeles Lakers. In his second N.B.A. season, Robertson averaged 30.8 points, 12.5 rebounds and 11.4 assists per game for Cincinnati.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynn Vavreck
title: A social science experiment suggests $100 vaccination incentives can pay off.
description: What’s the best way to persuade the millions of Americans to get their shots?
content: What’s the best way to persuade the millions of Americans to get their shots?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Lawmakers slam Facebook oversight board’s decision to uphold Trump ban.
description: “What’s to stop them from silencing you?” Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, replied on Twitter.
content: Lawmakers lashed out at the ruling by Facebook’s oversight board on Wednesday to uphold the social network’s ban on former President Donald J. Trump, at least for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Solomon
title: William T. Wiley, ‘Funk Artist’ Who Spurned Convention, Dies at 83
description: Rooted in the Bay Area, he spurned commerce (and the New York scene, mostly), produced an eclectic kind of figurative art and imparted his “Wiz-dumb” to disciples.
content: William T. Wiley, the influential artist and educator who helped found the funk art movement and establish the San Francisco Bay Area art scene as an unfiltered alternative to what he saw as the flagrant commercialism of New York, died on April 25 in a hospital in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Uber shows signs of recovery from the pandemic slowdown.
description: Excluding a settlement in Europe, Uber’s revenue in the first three months of the year was $3.5 billion, an 8 percent increase from the previous year.
content: Uber said its business was recovering from the slowdown caused by the pandemic, although it continued to lose money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Macron Condemns Napoleon’s Restoration of Slavery
description: The French president’s speech on the 200th anniversary of the emperor’s death combined a rebuke for a betrayal of the Enlightenment and recognition of his achievements.
content: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France, charting a delicate course between condemnation and celebration of Napoleon Bonaparte on the 200th anniversary of his death, said the emperor’s restoration of slavery in 1802 was a “mistake, a betrayal of the spirit of the Enlightenment.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: The pandemic may have accelerated the American drop in birthrates.
description: Early in the pandemic, there was speculation that the major changes in the life of American families could lead to a recovery in the birthrate as couples hunkered down together. In fact, the virus appeared to have had the opposite effect: Births were down most sharply at the end of the year, when babies conceived at the start of the pandemic would have been born.

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Who Gets Xanadu 2.0, the Gates Family Mansion?
description: Melinda Gates, at least, has been open about her desire to live in a smaller house.
content: As experts in philanthropy, finance, technology and global health scramble to predict what the divorce of Melinda and Bill Gates could mean for their industries, others are wondering: Who will get their lakefront estate in the Seattle suburbs, which is valued at upward of $131 million? And will the public finally get a peek inside?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton and Vanessa Friedman
title: What Will We Wear When It’s Over?
description: Be it the Saint Laurent fall offering or the Chanel cruise collection, designers are dreaming about what a post-pandemic wardrobe may look like.
content: For more than a year, the pandemic has put a hold on destination fashion events. And with vaccination rollouts across Europe only recently gaining pace, the first show of the cruise season — hosted by Chanel from inside the cavernous limestone quarries of Les Baux-de-Provence in the south of France — remained no exception.

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway Is Reopening. But Not Until September.
description: Even as New York City begins to reopen this summer, Broadway will not resume performances until Sept. 14. Here’s why.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo says that most pandemic capacity restrictions will ease in two weeks. Mayor Bill de Blasio says he wants the city to fully reopen on July 1. But Broadway, a beacon for tourists and an engine for the economy, is not quite ready to turn on the stage lights.

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Why Exercise Can Be So Draining for People With Rheumatoid Arthritis
description: Even a gentle session of leg lifts set off an exaggerated nervous system reaction in older women with rheumatoid arthritis.
content: Exercise can feel more difficult and draining than usual if you have rheumatoid arthritis, and it’s not just because of the stiff and painful joints caused by this autoimmune disorder. In a groundbreaking new experiment involving older women and exercise, researchers found that even a gentle session of leg lifts set off an exaggerated nervous system reaction in those with rheumatoid arthritis. Light exercise also negatively affected the inner workings of their muscles and blood vessels.
source.name: The New York Times

content: A total of 186,200 restaurants, bars and other eligible businesses applied for help from a new $28.6 billion federal aid program in the first two days it was accepting applications, President Biden said on Wednesday, indicating huge demand from a struggling industry for limited relief funds.

title: A Wide-Roaming and Personal Meditation on Dürer and His Art
description: With “Albert and the Whale,” the biographer and critic Philip Hoare trains his mind on the Renaissance artist Albrecht Dürer, then lets it drift to art history, nature writing and elements of memoir.
content: Philip Hoare began his career writing books about subjects like Noël Coward and Oscar Wilde. He has become a much stranger, singular thing: an obsessive chronicler of the sea, and specifically of whales. Beginning with “Leviathan or, The Whale” (2008), Hoare wrote three consecutive books — all personal, allusive and circuitous — about the ocean and its inhabitants.

author: By Megan Conway
title: Myung Eun Cha’s Avant-Garde Loungewear
description: Stuck in her apartment, the designer found inspiration in her surroundings, conceiving of a highly conceptual collection that provides literal support.
content: In March of last year, the fashion designer Myung Eun Cha had her friends fill out a survey on the nature of rest. She’d paused her graduate studies at London’s Central Saint Martins, opting instead, like so many of her peers, to wait out the pandemic’s spikes and dips back home in her apartment in Seoul. “My friends defined rest as a ‘free state of being alone, unconscious of anyone’s gaze,’” says Cha, 30. “Yet even if they were by themselves, they didn’t feel that because they were forced to stay at home with anxiety and worries about the near future.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Sofía Villamil
title: Colombia Police Respond to Protests With Bullets, and Death Toll Mounts
description: Strained by the pandemic and economic hardship, the country has exploded in anger. At least 24 people have died as the government cracks down.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — A teenager shot to death after kicking a police officer. A young man bleeding out on the street as protesters shout for help. Police firing on unarmed demonstrators. Helicopters swarming overhead, tanks rolling through neighborhoods, explosions echoing in the streets. A mother crying for her son.

content: On a recent “Jeopardy!” episode, one of the contestants, Mike Nelson, alighted upon a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. Nelson — “an actor originally from Chesterton, Indiana,” as the “Jeopardy!” announcer Johnny Gilbert introduced him — selected an $800 clue that triggered a Daily Double. It was Anderson Cooper’s first night guest-hosting the show, but Nelson had a different man in mind as he made his wager. “I’ve always wanted to say this,” Nelson said. “Let’s make it a true Daily Double” — and here Nelson closed his eyes and lifted his hands as if to signal for some kind of celestial field goal — “Alex.”
